sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: How? to drinke that poyson, ther's no just invitation to it.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: You will not drinke this poyson then, for Arviragus sake.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Even for his sake I must not.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Thou God of Love be judge, and crowne the truest Lover in Elisium—thus doe I seize my right.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: What meanes the Queen?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Force could not make thee do, what force shall not prevent me from this draught gives freedome, and all joyes to my deare Arviragus, nay makes even thee my hated rivall sharer in his blisse.

sp.speaker: Phi
sp.p: H • ld.—Car. No.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: O hold for Arviragus sake—shall I be thus outgone? this cursed draught to hell, how I am lost in admiration, at this love and bravery, here let me kneele in adoration, as to a Deity, for sure your beauty, and these exalted actions speake you more then a mortall.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: More then a foole, had I intended really, what I made show of.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: How is this?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Drink poyson for a man that scornes me—no • his heart-blood were a more pleasing draught.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I am amased, which way shall I direct my faith, where fixe it?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Vpon this point, which is unalterable, know that as much as I have loved Prince Arviragus, so much, nay more, hath Oswald been in love with me, (at last his service hath obtain'd what I could not from Arviragus,) beliefe and pitty of his sufferings, but whil'st the madnesse of my passion lasted to your servant, I made a vow never to marry any man, but Arviragus, yet hee alive, Oswald that knowes this, doth presse a combat, which I as gladly grant, prompted by love to him, and present hate to Arviragus, who yet if he proves victor, gaines liberty for • ou and him, to this my oath and honour both shall • ind me.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Can this be true?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I make no doubt of his and your acceptance, the offer being so farre above your hopes, Armour shall be provided, the place I likewise have designed, no witnesse but our selves,
This being perform'd, justice will force you say,
A Rivall to your joyes showed you a way.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: I must confesse you brave, performe but what you boast,
And I shall onely grieve your Oswald lost.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: My Lord, as to an Oracle I come for counsell to you, my mind is burdned with a secret of no finall importance.

sp.speaker: Sin.
sp.p: Be free in speaking it▪ I shall be so to you in my advice.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: First sweare a secresie.

sp.speaker: Sin.
sp.p:
You are not just sir, to desire an oath, I covet
not the knowledge of your secret, if you believe me honest, that's a tye sufficient.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: You righrly doe instruct me from that assurance I must discover to you, that woone by Eugenius, I have consented to his escape with his daughter, out at that which he committed to my custody, but considering better I find it is not onely his escape that he may ayme at, but happily the ruine of the King and City, whose weakenesse he may discover to the Danes and Arviragus.

sp.speaker: Sin.
sp.p: No doubt he does intend it, and these your latter thoughts had only power to wash away, ayded by the Kings mercy, the guilt that stain'd you by your rash consent.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: But if this be discovered, I prove the murtherer of Eugenius, and his sweet and innocent daughter.

sp.speaker: Sin.
sp.p: I shall advise you, as I have ever done my selfe, particular losses, must yeeld unto the generall preservation; and yet alas, is there no safety for the State but in their deaths? must that be recompence for all their former injuries? what is your will? the King must know this from you or me.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Sir, you are wise and vertuous, this my affaire I wholly commit unto your hands, for there I count my life or honour safe, if one must perish, it will be some comfort, that I lose it by your counsell.

sp.speaker: Sin.
sp.p: Althou • h unwillingly, yet as a Counseller, I am bound to undertake it, 'tis hard to rule what is above us, the King I feare dissembles, and thinkes by unjust pollicies, to bring his ends to passe.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Know now Sinatus consulting with your selfe.

sp.speaker: Sin.
sp.p: Yes, but about your safety.

sp.speaker: Gni.
sp.p: How am I in danger?

sp.speaker: Sin.
sp.p: Be pleas'd sir, first to tell me, if rash and unfaithfull resolutions may not find mercy, from repentance, and endeavours of amends?

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.p: They are crimes I have beene guilty of, and if like me, they truly can repent, I can forgive, as certaine, as I hope forgivenesse.

sp.speaker: Sin.
sp.p: I must believe you know then, I am inform'd Eugenius and Artemia, giving no faith to all your showes of love, did worke a meanes for their escape to Arv • ragus; the Captaine that made promise of his helpe, is hee that now discovers their intent.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.p: Thou wounds my soule with this, yet but from thee it could not find beliefe, have all my vowes and teares, gain'd no more faith? suspected still,—send straight to fetch that Captaine to me, and in what I shall now enjoyne thee, thou best of men, crowne all thy former actions.

sp.speaker: Sin.
sp.p: Let it be vertuous, and I shall know, nor doubt nor danger.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.p: I durst as soone pray heavens assistance, as thine to any unjust act, 'tis such a secret, as I scarce dare trust the ayre with it.

sp.speaker: Sin.
sp.p: How sir, 'twere madnesse.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.p: Feltst thou my torment, thou would'st account it madnesse not to doe it▪

sp.speaker: Sin.
sp.p: O sir, ther's too much danger.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: The more of love and honor then, He that like me, justly under the heavy burthen of suspition lies,
By actions, even above beliefe must seeke to rise.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p:
Hither I am come to meet an unknowne foe, by the command of her who hath so absolute a
power over my soule, that certaine death were by the merite of obedience, made a gainefull purchase, and farre from me be such a thought as death, were not my Armes as strong, my heart as voyd of feare, as any living, yet such a recompence will crowne my victory, that would give strength and courage, to the basest coward; my wish 'twas, that Cartandes vowed to make me master of, if in her power, and in her power, rests my chiefest blisse on earth, I am on fire till I behold an opposite, but whom? I must not question that, not in my thoughts, much lesse expostulate with him our cause of combat, were hee here.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: Were it a troupe of men, as 'tis a single person that I am to meet, I should encounter them with no lesse hope and courage then now, since 'tis to set Philicia free: Cartandes, prove but faithful in thy promise, and though thy hatred make thee seek my life, I shall admire thine, and thy servants bravery,—here's Oswald.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: I fear'd all was a dreame, but see my wish.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Enough Guiderius, hold, O hold Guiderius.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Ha, Guiderius.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: Why Madam, doe ye this?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: Do I here right? thy voyce speakes thee Guiderius, art thou hee?

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p:
Ha, if you be Arviragus, I shall soone be nothing,
O falshood, never till this minute hadst thou so glorious a seate, deare Lady take this sword and rip my heart, to see my innocence.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I should as soone suspect my faith, as doubt thy love to Arviragus.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: O Madam, could ye not be content to satisfie your cruelty a common way, but you would make us murtherers of our owne selves?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Prince Arviragus, I had really intended your destruction, perhaps you had not lived now to upbrayd me, your strengths & courages seeming equall, nor you Guiderius in your looks, to expresse a soule so discontented: I did not think friendship had wholly taken up your heart; call all that's neere, nay, could the universall world heare my voyce, I would with a just pride, proclaime the ground of all my actions—know Madame, in that Scene of death with you, I made such tryall of your vertue, and your love to Arviragus, that in the ocean of your merits, my sickly hopes were drownd, for I despaired of ever arriving at the haven of blisse, where you may now for ever anchor safely, from me no storme shall rise more to disturbe your peace.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: Can this be true Philicia, shall wee believe? will you not change againe?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Why doe you check your joyes? trust me I will no more vary the Scene, but gladly prove a Priest to joyne your hands.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: Oh you Gods!

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Let me adore this goodnesse.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Now Arviragus, I must turne to you: to make a repetition of the torments I have felt were vaine, for I must tell you, that I still doe love, and must enjoy all that your vertue can permit you grant, nay, I must marry Arviragus too▪

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: How Madam?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: In this his friend I shall enjoy, his faith, vertue, valour, in this last action fully witnest to me—Guiderius, if beyond this you have a wish, and in my power, name it, and I will see it performed.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: Or this, or in the instant give me death.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: This doubt speaks your love more, and makes you dearer to me.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: Let me not dare to thinke words can expresse my joyes.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Aldr.
sp.p: Some that are fled out of the City desire to be admitted to your presence.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Bring them in▪

div.stage: Enter Eugenius, Artemia, Guimanthes, and two more.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: First, let me here lay downe my necke, and if you please, receive a Traytors due.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: Eugenius I am both amaz'd and joyed to see you, and where you thinke you need forgivenesse, I must pay you thanks, even for my life, preserved by this your sonne.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: Your blessing sir.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: Never was fathers staines wip't off with so much joy to the offendor, as mine by thee.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Deare▪ Artemia wel come, here thou art safe from false-hood and tyranny.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.p: Madam, I hope so.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: But how sir did you scape the Tyrant?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p:
'Tis now some time since he made showes of love unto Artemia, and for his ends, used me with all respect, trusted the Government of the City to me, but I have gain'd the opportunity to put my selfe
within this gracious Princes and your protection, chiefely by imitating him in his dissimulation, but in his showes of love, her's one can witnesse to her griefe, none ever equal'd his falshood. Discovers.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.p: Eugenius, thus I doe disprove thy slander.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha the King!

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.p: Ha, deare Artemia, no longer trust the malice of this father, since to assure my love, I hazard honor, life and Kingdome, behold me here, gladly exposed, even to the utmost rage or injury can prompt you to, and if I fall a Sacrifice to Love, and thee close▪ but my eyes, and shed a teare upon my tombe, such a death will prove by far more welcome, ther 〈◊〉 to live, and have my faith suspected.
〈◊〉 his one act did not my interest bind, yet mig • t for ever reconcile us.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.p: I wil not beg that pardon, which you so freely give.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: And Madam, I must hope, you will believe, Hymen and Mars but ill agree.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Deare Arviragus know that power you held in both, is not grown lesse, because now we are joyn'd, dispose all how you please.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: Eugenius, are you as liberal?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.p: I am ready upon my knee to beg this Princes pardon.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.p: Which sir, I must not suffer, rather would kneele to beg a blessing from you.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: Artemia, if I can read loves language, your eyes expresse the argument of your heart, blush not; receive her sir.
I doe, as what can onely make me blest.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: Hymen provide more Torches:
sp.l: From your equall loves will rise,
A firme beliefe that Cupid now hath eyes.

div.head: Epilogue.
div.l: THus at the last, our doubtfull story ends,
With show of marriage, but our ioy depends
On your allowance, You may yet undoe
All that is past, and we againe must Wooe:
For by disliking You forbid our bands,
But if you'r pleas'd, you so do ioyne our hands.
